title: Enoki-class destroyer
text:
The were a <a href="ship%20class">class</a> of six <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a>. As with the previous , all were named after trees. As "Enoki" and "Nara" were both commissioned on the same day, the class is also referred to as the .
Background.
With most of Japan’s destroyers deployed to the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> as part of Japan’s contribution to the war effort against <a href="Imperial%20Germany">Imperial Germany</a> under the <a href="Anglo-Japanese%20Alliance">Anglo-Japanese Alliance</a>, the Imperial Japanese Navy approached the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a> for an emergency procurement budget, similar to that awarded during the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a> for the production of the destroyers. The funding was awarded from the fiscal 1917 budget, but mindful of the fact that the "Kamikaze"-class destroyers had not actually been completed until after the end of the previous war, the government stipulated that the emergency budget be used up within a six-month period.
The order for six vessels was split between the four major naval shipyards: one to <a href="Yokosuka%20Naval%20Arsenal">Yokosuka Naval Arsenal</a>, two to <a href="Kure%20Naval%20Arsenal">Kure Naval Arsenal</a>, two to <a href="Sasebo%20Naval%20Arsenal">Sasebo Naval Arsenal</a> and one to <a href="Maizuru%20Naval%20Arsenal">Maizuru Naval Arsenal</a>.
Design.
With such a limited time frame to use its budget, the Japanese Navy could not afford the time to design a new ship. Therefore, the <a href="blueprint">blueprint</a>s for the previous "Momo"-class destroyers were distributed to each shipyard, with the instructions that identical ships be produced, except with sturdier armor and <a href="bow%20%28ship%29">bow</a> construction. Experience with extended overseas deployment in World War I had taught the Japanese Navy that the construction of its destroyers needed to be reinforced to handle heavy seas. The result was a ship which looked physically almost exactly like the "Momo" class, but was roughly 15 tons heavier in displacement.
Internally, all six vessels used Brown-Curtis geared <a href="steam%20turbine">steam turbine</a> engines, which could use either <a href="heavy%20fuel%20oil">heavy fuel oil</a> or <a href="coal">coal</a> for propulsion. Armament was identical to the "Momo" class, with three <a href="QF%204.7%20inch%20Gun%20Mk%20I%20%E2%80%93%20IV">QF 4.7 inch Gun Mk I – IV</a> guns, pedestal mounted along the centerline of the vessel, front, mid-ship and to the <a href="stern">stern</a> and two triple <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> launchers.
Operational history.
The "Enoki"-class destroyers served in the very final stages of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, where they were deployed mostly in local waters near the <a href="Japanese%20home%20islands">Japanese home islands</a>. "Enoki" and "Nara" were converted to <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweepers</a> on 1 June 1930. The remaining four vessels were retired on 1 April 1934.
